awd_titl_txt: MRI: A Console Upgrade for a 500 MHz Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) Spectrometer Equipped with a Liquid Nitrogen-Cooled Probe to Aid Multidisciplinary Research and Education
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is supported by the Major Research Instrumentation and the Chemistry Research Instrumentation programs. Professor David Mootoo from CUNY Hunter College and colleagues Charles Drain and Matthew Devany have upgraded the console of a 500 MHz NMR spectrometer and have equipped the spectrometer with a liquid nitrogen cryoprobe. This upgraded spectrometer allows research in a variety of fields such as those that accelerate chemical reactions of significant economic importance, as well as those that allow study of biologically relevant species. In general, Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) spectroscopy is one of the most powerful tools available to chemists for the elucidation of the structure of molecules. It is used to identify unknown substances, to characterize specific arrangements of atoms within molecules, and to study the interactions between molecules in solution or in the solid state. Access to state-of-the-art NMR spectrometers is useful to chemists who are carrying out frontier research. The cryogenic probe provides a significant increase in sensitivity relative to standard NMR probes which permit use of small samples. The instrument is used for research and research training at this urban university and neighboring schools. Education and training in the science of NMR data interpretation is being accomplished in three overlapping ways: (1) via one-on-one interactions and workshops with the facility director; (2) in undergraduate courses and research experiences for undergraduates; and (3) through outreach activities that include demonstrations to high school and undergraduate students, for example, in the CUNY Math & Science Partnership Program.  This award provides research infrastructure that will benefit the national health, and innovation in industry as well as technical workforce development. 

The upgraded NMR spectrometer with a cryoprobe enhances research and education at all levels. It especially impacts studies of small molecules, biopolymers and natural product discovery. The instrument is used to establish combinatorial libraries and to search for biomechanistic probes. In addition, the spectrometer is used in the preparation of scaffolds for nanotechnology materials, and functionalized lipids and dyes. The instrument also serves researchers investigating materials for fuel cells and batteries, and for quantitation of small molecules in agricultural products.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The major goal of this project was to replace an 18-year old 500 MHz Nuclear Magnetic Resonance spectrometer that was a workhorse instrument for research and teaching primarily in the Chemistry and Physics departments at Hunter College, City University of New York (CUNY), with additional usage from the wider CUNY community. Outdated technology and recurring and increasingly frequent performance problems and concomitant downtime and loss in research productivity, made continued usage of this aged instrument untenable. The replacement, funded under NSF Award 1828399, is a current generation instrument, namely, a Bruker NEO 500 MHz NMR spectrometer with Bruker Prodigy nitrogen cooled broadband probe. The overall merit of this project relates to the discovery of new scientific knowledge and its relevance to education, human health and green technologies.

Unfortunately, delivery and installation of the instrument was delayed for more than two years into the funding period for this award, due to a combination of reasons, New York State (NYS) purchasing regulations, the federal shutdown in early 2019, manufacturing delays and travel and other restrictions imposed by the COVID pandemic. The instrument was finally installed by Bruker personnel in November 2020, the fourth month of final year of the award.  

As user protocols and the software packages on the old 500 MHz machine were similar to the new instrument, transitioning to the new machine was relatively seamless. The new machine is easier to use, more reliable and produces superior data, at higher throughput, for analysis of diverse materials. In addition, improvements in technology have resulted in significantly reduced maintenance costs. In the 12 months since installation, it has been used by over a dozen research groups, primarily at Hunter College, and the wider CUNY community, and enabled a broad range of experiments related to: (a) biologically relevant small molecules, (b) biopolymers, (c) natural product discovery (d) combinatorial libraries, (e) biomechanistic probes, (f) scaffolds for nanotechnology materials, (g) functionalized lipids and dyes (h) materials for fuel cells and batteries, and (i) quantitation of small molecules in agricultural products. This research includes studies on psychoactive compounds for treatment of addiction and cognitive disorders, materials and devices for diagnosis and treatment of carbohydrate-related diseases such as viral infection and cancer, signaling pathways of microbes as they relate to regulation of the immune system, radiopharmaceuticals and alternative energy sources.   

Beyond bolstering the quality and productivity of scientific research at Hunter College, the new NEO NMR is having a wider impact on education and new pedagogy. In this vein, the instrument is being used to develop fundamental concepts on molecular structure and dynamics in our undergraduate and graduate courses, thereby exposing students to cutting edge technology and broadening their scientific base. On a more general note, this is part of a pedagogical strategy to motivate learning, by incorporating real-life examples and data into traditional classroom courses. The long term objectives of this initiative are to draw students to, and better prepare them for STEM careers. Given the student population at Hunter College, comprising 67% women and 40% students from populations that are underrepresented in sciences, this program stands to increase diversity in the scientific workforce

In summary, the new NEO 500 MHz NMR purchased under NSF Award 1828399, has strengthened the research infrastructure at Hunter College and CUNY, thereby enhancing research and pedagogy in the life and physical sciences across the diverse college community. These results in the short term are contributing to new fundamental knowledge and materials, which have broader impact on improvement in human health, environmental preservation, education, and diversity in the scientific workforce.
